The Act may be cited as the "Berta Caceres Human Rights in Honduras Act". Congress finds that the Honduran police are corrupt and commit human rights abuses with impunity, including torture, rape, illegal detention, and murder. The New York Times revealed documents showing top police officials ordered the killings of drug-crime investigators in 2009 and 2011, with knowledge of high-ranking government officials. Individuals in the police with records of human rights abuses continue to act with impunity. The Honduran police are corrupt and commit human rights abuses with impunity, including killings. International human rights bodies and reports highlight the police's use of lethal force and inefficiency in investigating abuses, leading to a culture of impunity. The Honduran police face challenges in prosecuting officials for human rights violations, with slow progress in cleaning up corruption. Reforms are needed for lasting change. Rights Action documented the involvement of the Fifteenth Battalion of the Honduran Armed Forces in killings of small-farmer activists in the Aguan Valley since 2000. Human Rights Watch confirmed lack of consequences for these killings in 2015. Only one private actor has been convicted so far. Key activists continue to be assassinated, such as Jose Angel Flores and Silmer Dionisio George in October 2016. Other instances of human rights abuses by the military include the shooting of Lenca Indigenous activist Tomas Garcia in July 2013. The military in Honduras has been involved in various human rights abuses, including the killing of Indigenous activists and Afro-Indigenous men. The government has expanded the military's role into domestic policing, creating a Military Police force in violation of the law. These cases remain unresolved, with impunity for those responsible. The Honduran military's expansion into domestic policing, with the creation of a 3,000-member Military Police force, has led to human rights abuses and killings of civilians passing through checkpoints. The judicial system in Honduras is plagued with corruption, with officials linked to organized crime. The justice system in Honduras is corrupt, with officials connected to organized crime and drug traffickers, leading to widespread impunity. Efforts to reform the system have been ineffective, as reported by the Department of State and Human Rights Watch. The assassination of activist Berta Caceres in 2016 highlights the ongoing issues of crime and impunity in the country. The assassination of activist Berta Caceres in 2016 exemplifies the human rights crisis in Honduras, showcasing the government's failure to protect her despite numerous threats reported. The killing of Berta Caceres in 2016 raises concerns about the involvement of Honduran military personnel in her assassination, with eight suspects arrested, including current and former military officers. The government restricts access to the case file, which was stolen in late September 2016. The Honduran government has not allowed an independent investigation into the case of Berta Caceres despite calls from various organizations. Activists and critics of the government are at risk of human rights abuses, with previous abuses largely going unpunished. Activists, human rights defenders, and government critics in Honduras face severe risks, with past abuses often unpunished. The shooting of journalist Felix Molina in 2016 highlighted the ongoing dangers. The US allocated $18 million to Honduran police and military in 2016, with plans for increased security funding in 2017. The Inter-American Development Bank lent $59,800,000 to the Honduran police in 2012 with US approval. SEC. 3. Suspension of security assistance to Honduras' police and military unless specific conditions are met. No funds for equipment or training. Secretary of the Treasury to vote against loans for Honduran police or military at multilateral development banks.

SEC. 4. Conditions for lifting suspensions and restrictions. The Act will end when the Secretary of State certifies that Honduras has pursued legal action for various murders and human rights violations, including the killings of activists and armed attacks. Military and police members found guilty of human rights violations must be prosecuted. Honduras must ensure military and police forces stop violating human rights, withdraw military from domestic policing, protect the rights of various groups, and establish the rule of law effectively. Honduras must guarantee the rule of law and a capable judicial system to prosecute police and military members for human rights abuses.
